evidence_items.text: A tug driving instructor (tug instructor) and trainee tug driver (trainee driver) were seated beside each other in the tug. The flight crew were in communication with the headset operator via the aircraft’s interphone.
The trainee driver decided to stop the pushback and asked the tug instructor to take over.

After swapping seats the instructor recommenced the pushback, correcting the aircraft back onto the taxiway centreline. He continued to reassure and advise the trainee while performing the pushback, looking at her while doing so. The headset operator continued walking on the right side of the tug, abeam its cabin. The wingman was on the left just ahead of the tug.

The aircraft’s nosewheel reached the ‘Tug release point’ (TRP) ground markings. However, it continued moving beyond the TRP with its engine at idle and hit the blast barrier at the end of the cul-de-sac.
The tug instructor pulled the aircraft forward off the fence then stopped the tug.

The airport operator and ATC were notified. Soon after, representatives from the airport operator and the RFFS were on scene. The aircraft sustained substantial damage to the rear of the aircraft, including the APU, which was running at the time.
The TRP on Taxiway Delta is between Stands 61L and 61R. There is a 14.97 m clearance behind a B737-800 and the blast fence when its nosewheel is on the TRP.

The tug instructor stated that the method for getting a tug driver to stop quickly was to raise a clenched first, indicating the driver should apply the tug’s brakes. However, he suggested such a visual signal was not sufficient given a driver would be concentrating on the pushback, with the headset operator often out of his field of view. He did not receive any warning of the impending collision from the wingman or the headset operator.

Trainee tug driver The trainee driver was qualified as a headset operator and wingman, and was aware of the TRP through the training for these roles. This was her second pushback. The first was completed earlier that day, without event.

The trainee driver reported that she felt the tug slow down as the aircraft’s nose wheel approached the TRP, so believed the instructor would stop the pushback. However, she did not say anything when he drove past the TRP, assuming he must have known what he was doing. After the collision, she suggested not moving the aircraft off the blast fence.
Headset operator The headset operator was also qualified as a wingman. Prior to this accident, he knew about TRPs from his training for the headset operator role but had not physically seen one.

He commented that the tug instructor took over when the aircraft was abeam Stand 62 and thereafter was attending to talking to the trainee. The tug slowed down when the aircraft was abeam Stand 61, so he positioned himself to disconnect the tug from the aircraft when it stopped. However, the aircraft continued to move slowly until it hit the blast fence. He said he assumed the instructor had a reason for that and did not question his actions.

Wingman The wingman was also a qualified headset operator. On the day of the accident, he had been called into work at short notice. To avoid delaying the pushback, he had not collected the marshalling wands from the tug. Nevertheless, it was not mandatory to use them. He commented that the TRP was quite small.

slot_statements.availability: Communication/coordination breakdown among crew occurred during the Boeing 737-8AS 9H-QAA flight on 12-25 in the hist_t3_prefinal phase.
slot_statements.defeater_resistance: The communication/coordination breakdown among crew is resistant to defeaters given the evidence from the Boeing 737-8AS 9H-QAA 12-25 hist_t3_prefinal data, showing consistent patterns without contradictory information.
slot_statements.fit_to_key_features: The communication/coordination breakdown among crew aligns with key features observed in the Boeing 737-8AS 9H-QAA 12-25 hist_t3_prefinal scenario, such as timing and crew interactions.

slot_statements.availability: The environmental or marking deficiency must be present and observable in the Boeing 737-8AS 9H-QAA during the hist_t3_prefinal inspection phase on 12-25.
slot_statements.defeater_resistance: The identification of the environmental or marking deficiency must be robust against potential defeaters or counter-evidence during the hist_t3_prefinal inspection of the Boeing 737-8AS 9H-QAA.
slot_statements.fit_to_key_features: The environmental or marking deficiency should align with the key features and criteria defined for the Boeing 737-8AS 9H-QAA in the hist_t3_prefinal inspection phase.

slot_statements.availability: Mechanical/control failure was present in the Boeing 737-8AS 9H-QAA during the hist_t3_prefinal phase on 12-25.
slot_statements.defeater_resistance: The mechanical/control failure in the Boeing 737-8AS 9H-QAA during the hist_t3_prefinal phase on 12-25 shows resistance to defeaters based on available evidence.
slot_statements.fit_to_key_features: The mechanical/control failure aligns with the key features observed in the Boeing 737-8AS 9H-QAA during the hist_t3_prefinal phase on 12-25.

slot_statements.availability: The procedural deviation in pushback execution is documented and accessible within the Boeing 737-8AS 9H-QAA 12-25 historical prefinal records.
slot_statements.defeater_resistance: The procedural deviation in pushback execution withstands scrutiny against potential counterarguments or exceptions within the Boeing 737-8AS 9H-QAA 12-25 historical prefinal context.
slot_statements.fit_to_key_features: The procedural deviation in pushback execution aligns with the key features observed in the Boeing 737-8AS 9H-QAA 12-25 historical prefinal data, reflecting typical operational variances.

children_spec.statement: Crew members were physically present and reachable during the operation
children_spec.test_procedure: Check crew attendance logs, communication device records, and physical presence reports to confirm availability

children_spec.statement: Communication devices and channels were operational and accessible to all crew members
children_spec.test_procedure: Verify maintenance records and test communication equipment functionality during the incident timeframe

children_spec.statement: Crew members were not incapacitated or otherwise unable to communicate during the event
children_spec.test_procedure: Review medical and incident reports to determine if any crew member was incapacitated or impaired

children_spec.statement: Mechanical components required for control are physically present and intact
children_spec.test_procedure: Inspect the aircraft's mechanical control components for presence and physical integrity; absence or damage would lower availability

children_spec.statement: Mechanical control components are free from obstructions or blockages
children_spec.test_procedure: Check for any physical obstructions or blockages in the mechanical control pathways; detection of obstructions would reduce availability

children_spec.statement: Mechanical control components are properly connected and linked to control inputs
children_spec.test_procedure: Verify mechanical linkages and connections between control inputs and control surfaces; disconnections or misalignments would lower availability

children_spec.statement: Mechanical control components are free from wear or damage that impairs function
children_spec.test_procedure: Examine mechanical parts for wear, corrosion, or damage that could impair control function; presence of such issues would reduce availability

children_spec.statement: Crew members failed to share critical flight information in a timely manner
children_spec.test_procedure: Review cockpit voice recorder transcripts and communication logs to identify delays or omissions in information sharing

children_spec.statement: Crew did not follow established communication protocols during the flight
children_spec.test_procedure: Compare crew communication behavior against standard operating procedures and checklists

children_spec.statement: Crew coordination was impaired by misunderstandings or misinterpretations of instructions
children_spec.test_procedure: Analyze recorded communications and crew interviews for evidence of confusion or misinterpretation

children_spec.statement: External factors such as noise or equipment malfunction hindered effective communication among crew
children_spec.test_procedure: Inspect cockpit audio equipment and environmental conditions to assess impact on communication clarity

children_spec.statement: Required environmental markings are physically present at the location
children_spec.test_procedure: Inspect the location to verify the presence of all required environmental markings

children_spec.statement: Required environmental markings are visible and legible under operational conditions
children_spec.test_procedure: Assess visibility and legibility of markings during typical operational lighting and weather conditions

children_spec.statement: Required environmental markings are maintained and not obscured or damaged
children_spec.test_procedure: Examine markings for signs of wear, damage, or obstruction that would reduce effectiveness

children_spec.statement: The environmental conditions at the time match the key features of the deficiency
children_spec.test_procedure: Compare recorded environmental data (weather, lighting, visibility) with the expected conditions that define the deficiency; discrepancies would lower the probability

children_spec.statement: The physical markings or signage present correspond to the key features of the deficiency
children_spec.test_procedure: Inspect and document the markings or signage at the location and compare them to the expected deficient markings; inconsistencies would reduce confidence

children_spec.statement: The environmental or marking deficiency is consistent with prior similar incidents or reports
children_spec.test_procedure: Review historical incident reports and maintenance records for similar deficiencies; absence of such reports would lower the likelihood

children_spec.statement: Availability of required pushback equipment at the time of operation
children_spec.test_procedure: Check maintenance and operational logs for equipment readiness and downtime records during the pushback event

children_spec.statement: Availability of trained personnel to perform pushback according to procedure
children_spec.test_procedure: Review crew rosters, training records, and duty schedules to confirm presence of qualified staff during the pushback

children_spec.statement: Availability of clear communication channels between pushback team and flight crew
children_spec.test_procedure: Analyze communication logs and recordings to verify if communication was established and maintained as per procedure

children_spec.statement: The pushback procedure deviated from the standard communication protocol between the flight crew and ground personnel
children_spec.test_procedure: Review recorded communications and transcripts to identify any deviations from the prescribed communication steps

children_spec.statement: The pushback procedure did not follow the prescribed sequence of control inputs and checks as per the Boeing 737-8AS standard operating procedures
children_spec.test_procedure: Analyze cockpit voice recorder and flight data recorder to verify adherence to the control input sequence and checklist completion

children_spec.statement: The pushback vehicle operator did not comply with the required safety and positioning protocols during the pushback maneuver
children_spec.test_procedure: Examine ground vehicle logs, surveillance footage, and operator reports to confirm compliance with safety and positioning protocols

children_spec.statement: The environmental conditions at the time did not degrade the visibility of markings
children_spec.test_procedure: Assess weather reports, lighting conditions, and any obstructions to determine if markings were visible

children_spec.statement: The markings were applied according to regulatory standards and were intact
children_spec.test_procedure: Inspect maintenance records and physical evidence of markings for compliance and condition

children_spec.statement: No external factors such as dirt, wear, or damage reduced the effectiveness of the markings
children_spec.test_procedure: Examine the aircraft and environment for signs of contamination or damage affecting markings

node.statement: Required environmental markings are visible and legible under operational conditions

defeaters: Direct observation or measurement of the visibility and legibility of the environmental markings under operational conditions
Statements from operators explicitly confirming visibility and legibility of markings

quotes.exact_quote: The TRP on Taxiway Delta is between Stands 61L and 61R. There is a 14.97 m clearance behind a B737-800 and the blast fence when its nosewheel is on the TRP.
He commented that the TRP was quite small.

outcome.reasoning_summary: Evidence indicates the TRP marking exists but is described as 'quite small' (H13) and the aircraft passed beyond it causing collision (H7), suggesting markings may not be sufficiently visible or legible under operational conditions.
outcome.uncertainty_source: ambiguity in the description of marking size and no direct evidence on visibility or legibility

children_spec.statement: The mechanical components show wear or damage consistent with failure modes documented for the Boeing 737-8AS
children_spec.test_procedure: Inspect mechanical components for wear or damage and compare with known failure mode documentation

children_spec.statement: Control system logs indicate anomalies or errors consistent with mechanical/control failure
children_spec.test_procedure: Analyze control system logs for error codes or anomalies that match mechanical/control failure patterns

children_spec.statement: Physical examination confirms that control linkages and actuators are not functioning as designed
children_spec.test_procedure: Perform functional tests on control linkages and actuators to verify operational status

children_spec.statement: The mechanical components show signs of wear or damage that could cause failure
children_spec.test_procedure: Inspect mechanical parts for wear, cracks, or deformation; evidence of such damage would increase the likelihood of failure

children_spec.statement: Control system linkages or cables are intact and properly connected
children_spec.test_procedure: Physically verify the integrity and connection of control linkages and cables; disconnection or damage would lower resistance to failure

children_spec.statement: No external factors such as foreign object debris or environmental conditions are impairing mechanical control function
children_spec.test_procedure: Examine the control environment for debris, ice, or other impairments; presence of such factors would reduce defeater resistance

children_spec.statement: Maintenance records confirm recent inspections and repairs have addressed potential mechanical issues
children_spec.test_procedure: Review maintenance logs for recent inspections and repairs; absence of such records would lower confidence in defeater resistance

node.statement: Mechanical components required for control are physically present and intact

defeaters: Evidence showing mechanical components were missing or damaged
Evidence confirming mechanical components were physically present and intact
outcome.reasoning_summary: No evidence in the provided history items (H1-H13) addresses the physical presence or intactness of mechanical components required for control.

children_spec.statement: Crew members failed to share critical information in a timely manner
children_spec.test_procedure: Review cockpit voice recordings and communication logs to identify delays or omissions in information sharing

children_spec.statement: Crew coordination protocols were not followed during the event
children_spec.test_procedure: Analyze adherence to standard operating procedures and checklists during the incident

children_spec.statement: Misinterpretation of communicated information occurred among crew members
children_spec.test_procedure: Examine transcripts and crew interviews for evidence of misunderstandings or incorrect assumptions

node.statement: Crew members were physically present and reachable during the operation

defeaters: If evidence showed any crew member was absent or unreachable during the operation
If communication devices were non-functional preventing reachability

quotes.exact_quote: A tug driving instructor (tug instructor) and trainee tug driver (trainee driver) were seated beside each other in the tug. The flight crew were in communication with the headset operator via the aircraft’s interphone.

After swapping seats the instructor recommenced the pushback, correcting the aircraft back onto the taxiway centreline. He continued to reassure and advise the trainee while performing the pushback, looking at her while doing so. The headset operator continued walking on the right side of the tug, abeam its cabin. The wingman was on the left just ahead of the tug.

The tug instructor stated that the method for getting a tug driver to stop quickly was to raise a clenched first, indicating the driver should apply the tug’s brakes. However, he suggested such a visual signal was not sufficient given a driver would be concentrating on the pushback, with the headset operator often out of his field of view. He did not receive any warning of the impending collision from the wingman or the headset operator.
Headset operator The headset operator was also qualified as a wingman. Prior to this accident, he knew about TRPs from his training for the headset operator role but had not physically seen one.

He commented that the tug instructor took over when the aircraft was abeam Stand 62 and thereafter was attending to talking to the trainee. The tug slowed down when the aircraft was abeam Stand 61, so he positioned himself to disconnect the tug from the aircraft when it stopped. However, the aircraft continued to move slowly until it hit the blast fence. He said he assumed the instructor had a reason for that and did not question his actions.

To avoid delaying the pushback, he had not collected the marshalling wands from the tug. Nevertheless, it was not mandatory to use them. He commented that the TRP was quite small.

outcome.reasoning_summary: Evidence H1, H3, H8, H11, H12, and H13 directly describe the physical presence and roles of crew members (tug instructor, trainee driver, headset operator, wingman) during the operation, confirming they were physically present and reachable.
outcome.uncertainty_source: No explicit mention of any crew member being unreachable, but some ambiguity about effectiveness of visual signals and situational awareness

node.statement: Communication devices and channels were operational and accessible to all crew members

assumptions: Interphone and other communication devices were operational as implied by usage
Crew members had physical access to communication devices during pushback
defeaters: Evidence of explicit communication failures or device malfunctions
Reports of crew members being unable to access communication devices
Statements confirming all crew members actively used communication channels effectively

quotes.exact_quote: The flight crew were in communication with the headset operator via the aircraft’s interphone.
He did not receive any warning of the impending collision from the wingman or the headset operator.
She did not say anything when he drove past the TRP, assuming he must have known what he was doing.
He said he assumed the instructor had a reason for that and did not question his actions.

outcome.reasoning_summary: Evidence shows communication devices (interphone) were operational (H1), but key personnel (tug instructor, trainee, headset operator) did not warn or correct the pushback beyond the TRP (H8, H10, H12), indicating communication was accessible but ineffective or not fully utilized.
outcome.uncertainty_source: No direct evidence on whether all crew members had equal access or used communication devices effectively; ambiguity about communication quality and situational awareness.

children_spec.statement: The procedural deviation was not corrected by the flight crew during pushback
children_spec.test_procedure: Review cockpit voice recordings and crew reports to determine if any corrective actions were taken during pushback

children_spec.statement: Ground personnel did not intervene to prevent or correct the procedural deviation during pushback
children_spec.test_procedure: Examine ground crew communications and procedures to verify if any intervention occurred

children_spec.statement: The aircraft systems did not detect or alert the crew about the procedural deviation during pushback
children_spec.test_procedure: Analyze aircraft system logs and alerts to check for any warnings related to pushback procedures
